docs.lead_paragraph: One of the big mistakes that the more extremist Republican politicians make is thinking that when they campaign on conservative ideas like small government and lower taxes, and then get elected, that they have a mandate to pursue every wing-nut idea that pops into their heads.
docs.abstract: Do yesterday's election results in Ohio suggest that GOP extremism has jumped the shark?
docs.snippet: Do yesterday's election results in Ohio suggest that GOP extremism has jumped the shark?

docs.lead_paragraph: A financial planner recounts how he and his family fell victim to the housing boom and bust and how they survived the ordeal.

headline.seo: How a Financial Pro Lost His House
headline.main: How a Financial Pro Lost His House
headline.print_headline: ‘I Should Have Known Better’: How a Financial Pro Lost His House

docs.abstract: Carl Richards, financial planner and author of The Behavior Gap: Simple Ways to Stop Doing Dumb Things With Money, recounts how he and his family survived the ordeal of losing their house in Las Vegas, Nev, during the housing bust.
docs.snippet: A financial planner recounts how he and his family fell victim to the housing boom and bust and how they survived the ordeal.

docs.lead_paragraph: Of four appellate court rulings on the Affordable Care Act so far, a federal appeals court in Washington is the third to deal with the law on the merits, and the second that upholds it.

headline.main: Health Law Survives Test in Court of Appeals
headline.print_headline: Health Law Survives Test In Court Of Appeals

docs.abstract: Federal appeals court upholds the Obama administration's health care law in a decision written by prominent conservative Judge Laurence H Silberman; of four appellate court rulings on the Affordable Care Act so far, Silberman's ruling is the third to deal with the law on its merits and the second to uphold it; decision comes as the Supreme Court is about to consider whether to take up challenges to the law.
docs.snippet: Of four appellate court rulings on the Affordable Care Act so far, a federal appeals court in Washington is the third to deal with the law on the merits, and the second that upholds it.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.abstract: With a supercommittee and a “group of four” involved, can a food system be improved?
docs.snippet: With a supercommittee and a “group of four” involved, can a food system be improved?

docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican-manufactured budget crisis of this past summer - remember? - resulted in a "solution" that's hijacking what little representative democratic process we have left. Equally sad is that the so-called supercommittee - charged with creating an outline for reducing the deficit by $1.2 trillion over 10 years - may preclude full discussion of the farm bill.
docs.abstract: With a supercommittee and a "group of four" involved, can a food system be improved?
docs.snippet: With a supercommittee and a "group of four" involved, can a food system be improved?

docs.lead_paragraph: FAULKNER--Walter T. Sound Shore Health System mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Walter T. Faulkner. Together with his family, Walter was a steadfast supporter of Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester and a devoted member of the Board of Governors, serving from 1985 to 2009. During this time he was active on the Law and Insurance Committees. His commitment to providing our community with the highest level of health care services by furthering the mission of the Medical Center will be forever remembered at Sound Shore. We will miss his guidance and support. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his to his wife Joan and their family. Mauro C. Romita, Chairman John R. Spicer, Pres. & CEO

docs.lead_paragraph: With the deficit-cutting panel close to a deadlock, Republicans now want to undo it. But walking away would be a blow to Washington’s financial credibility.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges the Congressional Joint Select Committee on Deficit Reduction to overcome deadlock and come up with a plan that balances new revenues with spending cuts; argues that if Republicans dismiss the committee because they refuse to compromise, it will have dire consequences for the economy and the country.
docs.snippet: With the deficit-cutting panel close to a deadlock, Republicans now want to undo it. But walking away would be a blow to Washington’s financial credibility.
